newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian shares in sharp losses, Bombay off 3.60 pct.
newsitem.headline: Indian shares in sharp losses, Bombay off 3.60 pct.

text.p: ** (1230 GMT) Indian stocks hit by major sell-off as some
foreign funds turn sellers in blue chips, dealers say
** Bombay index in correction after four day weekend; ends
** Local speculators unload positions as Bombay bourse
reopens Tuesday following a four-day break
** National exchange index off 20.75 pts, or 1.72 pct at
1,180.70 on last day of weekly trade account
** Delhi index slides 22.42 pts to 884.84, Madras down
10.26 pts to 4,410.87 and Calcutta 1.29 pts to 118.07
A major sell-off in blue chips on Tuesday dragged Indian stock markets lower with the Bombay index posting its biggest fall in nearly five months, traders said.
The Bombay Stock Exchange re-opened after a four day weekend, which mitigated the scale of Tuesday's decline.
The National Stock Exchange, which was open had fallen more than two percent on Monday, and today's fall on the BSE was largely to catch up.
The Bombay index shed 155.35 points, or 3.60 percent to close at 4,165.37.
The Bombay index fall was the biggest after a nearly 300 point, eight percent, tumble in March this year.

Investors should see falling prices as an opportunity to buy, Caspian Research India Pvt Ltd said. "The volatility of the next four to five months should be viewed as opportunity to accumulate stock," the securities firm said in its latest report.
The fall in share prices is a logical correction after the benchmark Bombay Stock Exchange index had soared 60 percent from a three-year low reached in December 1996, it said.
